Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Tackling the "right" problem: Investigating cognitive strategies used in understanding engineering problems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
How do engineers find the 'right' design problem to solve, rather than the one first presented? This project will identify engineers' cognitive strategies for understanding design problems, called Problem Exploration Heuristics. The project is investigating problem exploration in professional design settings and in engineering classrooms through a combination of laboratory experiments and field studies. Engineers at multiple levels of expertise (professional to undergraduate students) working in differing settings are included to improve the generalizability of the findings. The project includes three phases: 1) in-depth interviews, observations, and protocol studies with engineering practitioners; 2) classroom studies of engineering and design students' perceptions of presented problems, and the ways in which they explore problems as individuals and teams; and, 3) synthesis of the findings into teachable heuristics to support STEM education.

The intellectual merit of the project includes identification of the nature of these cognitive strategies as they occur in context (including when they are employed, and how they impact outcomes), and will inform the creation of instructional materials to promote innovation in problem exploration. The broader impact of this work includes improvement in the variety, novelty, and quality of designs through the use of problem exploration heuristics. The project findings directly support better design practices to address the core engineering problems of the 21st Century. In addition to support from the IUSE program, this work is also supported by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today’s world is changing at an accelerating rate, intensifying the need for innovation in engineering. The proposed research investigates problem exploration heuristics as strategies used to identify and refine problem understanding and definition. Problem exploration entails restructuring problems so as to lead to more varied and creative solutions. For example, a “lack of firewood” might lead to increasing the amount of resources; however, a restructuring of the problem might lead to a search for alternative fuel sources, or more efficient stove designs. Problems that lead to creative solutions are rarely solved with systematic, linear approaches; instead, people often use heuristics to “guess” at a possible solution. These cognitive heuristics help designers go from a surface problem description to identify deeper, more novel approaches to innovative solutions. Knowledge about how to perform problem exploration is important for improving our understanding of perceived problems, and how to turn them into successful engineering design solutions. Identification, development, and pursuit of inventive problems are skills that are rarely taught, developed, or assessed in engineering education, but are essential to innovative solutions.

 

In this project, we investigated how engineers explore problems using cognitive strategies, called heuristics. We documented how engineering designers explore problems to create new opportunities for their solution. While the problem finding stage is identified in process models of design, strategies for accomplishing problem exploration in engineering have rarely been empirically tested. Through analysis of design competition outcomes and protocol studies of engineers’ practices, we extracted and characterized the heuristics that successfully led to finding, developing, and restructuring problems.

 

In one study, we conducted a qualitative analysis of 252 design problems collected from publicly available sources, including award-winning product designs and open-source design competitions. A total of 32 distinct patterns of problem exploration were identified across designers and presented problems. In another study, 35 engineering students and practitioners explored  design problems and generated solutions while we recorded their verbal thoughts. A set of 27 patterns for problem exploration emerged from the data, both overlapping, adding to, and refining the strategies uncovered in our first study.  The patterns document the strategies engineers employed in exploring problem spaces across problem contexts. The data provide evidence that engineering designers, working individually, apply problem exploration heuristics  when exploring design problems.

 

The broader impact of this work lies in the improvement in the variety, novelty, and quality of designs that follow from the use of problem exploration heuristics . These results will support development of instructional materials for dissemination in educational and corporate settings in order to assist practitioners in their problem exploration processes. We will provide instructional lessons based on Problem Exploration Heuristics, videos of ‘how to’ teach these lessons, short tutorials, examples of design problems with differing explorations, project plans for each of the lessons, and examples from design competitions. The project findings will directly help to better prepare engineers to develop problem understanding in ways that facilitate innovative solutions, ultimately resulting in solutions that address the real problems of our world.
